description: Ultimately from Ancient Greek παράνοια (paránoia, “madness”), from παράνοος (paránoos, “demented”), from παρά (pará, “beyond, beside”) + νόος (nóos, “mind, spirit”).
Surface analysis is para- (“abnormal, beyond”) +‎ nous (“mind”) +‎ -ia (“(medical) condition”).

nouns.description: paranoia (countable and uncountable, plural paranoias or (archaic) paranoiæ)

entries.meaning: The obsolete name for a psychotic disorder, now called delusional disorder, often (in one of 6 subtypes) characterized by delusions of persecution and perceived threat against the individual affected with the disorder, and often associated with false accusations and general mistrust of others
